title-group.article-title: Water vapor permeability and tensile properties of poly(l-lactic acid)/synthetic mica nanocomposites prepared by melt blending

abstract.p: Poly(L-lactic acid)/synthetic mica (Somasif) nanocomposites were obtained by melt blending in a mixing chamber according to a factorial experimental design and considering the following variables: temperature, rotor speed, nanofiller concentration and residence time. Relatively high degree of dispersion was attained by the melt processing which generates poly(L-lactic acid)/synthetic mica nanocomposites with particle size even in the order of 40 nm. The tensile properties and the water vapor permeability of these nanocomposites were evaluated. The introduction of synthetic mica into neat poly(L-lactic acid) decreased the water vapor permeability by about 50%. The variables which most affected the tensile properties were the mixing time and clay concentration, but the levels studied or the degree of intercalation/exfoliation were insufficient to significantly improve the tensile properties of poly(L-lactic acid)/somasif mica nanocomposites.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Research into biodegradable materials for food packaging has significantly increased in the last decades due to new requirements for environmental protection and awareness that oil resources are limited and that packaging from renewable raw materials is therefore desirable. Packaging based on poly(lactic acid) (PLLA) is a viable alternative because it is biodegradable, compostable and safe for food and human contact. In addition, PLLA can be produced on a large scale using renewable resources and presents mechanical properties similar to some commercially available oil-based polymers such as polystyrene.1–5

Among the disadvantages of the PLLA, it has high cost, low thermal resistance, brittleness in the amorphous state and the relatively low barrier properties to gas permeation,3 which can be overcome by blending the polymer with other biodegradable polymers or by adding nanofillers (creating nanocomposites) such as organically modified layered silicates.6–11

Melt processing via extrusion can be an effective method for obtaining polymer nanocomposites based on layered silicates due to its good polymer intercalation or exfoliation and the ability for large-scale industrial production with little or no residue generation.6,9,12–17

According to a recent review of layered silicate polymer-based nanocomposites published by Pavlidou and Papaspyrides,4 the degree of clay intercalation or exfoliation in the polymer matrix is dependent on the polymer–clay interaction, which depends on the chemical nature and concentration of both components and the shear generated under the extrusion conditions (temperature, screw speed, residence time and screw-extruder configuration). The degree of clay intercalation affects the mechanical and barrier properties of the material. In general, adequate conditions lead to an improvement in the mechanical properties and a decrease in the gas permeability, which are required for food packaging applications.

In comparison with commercially available organo-nanoclays, synthetic micas have several advantages over other natural clays, including high crystallinity and their degree of purity, a controllable composition, a high aspect ratio18,19 and a higher biodegradability rate.20 Nevertheless, few studies have been conducted on nanocomposite production using these layered silicates.

This work reports an investigation of the influence of processing conditions used in the preparation of nanocomposites on the mechanical properties and the water vapor permeability of synthetic organophilic mica Somasif MAE and PLLA prepared by melt blending in a mixing chamber.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Poly(L-lactic acid) (PLLA) Ingeo 2002D with Mn = 121,100 and Mw/Mn = 1.63 measured by GPC in CHCl3 and low D-unity content was furnished by Nature Works (Minnetonka, USA). The synthetic organophilic mica Somasif MAE was provided by CO-OP Chemical Co. Ltd., Japan. This mica contains (CH3)2 N+(HT)2 (HT is a hydrogenated tallow: ∼65% C18, ∼30% C16, ∼5% C14) as an intercalant and presents a cation-exchange capacity (CEC) of 120 meq/100 g.5 Morphology characterization of this mica was previously reported in the literature.21

sec.title: Experimental design
sec.p:
An experimental incomplete factorial (24−1) design with a 3 central points repetition was used in this work (Table 1).22 The factorial experiment aimed to evaluate effects such as the temperature of the mixing chamber; the mixer rotor speed; the synthetic mica concentration and the extrusion time on the morphology; the thermal, mechanical and transport properties. All results were analyzed using STATISTICA 5.0 software. Table 1.

sec.title: Nanocomposite preparation
sec.p: A mixture of PLLA–Somasif MAE (70 g), dried separately in a oven at 110°C according to the literature,17 was processed in a Haake Rheocord 9000 torque rheometer (Germany) equipped with a Rheomix 600 internal mixer and roller rotors according to the conditions of the experimental design. The amount of mixture used was calculated based on the utilization of a minimum of 70% of the chamber volume (69 mL) and the density of each mixture. The processing was done in air atmosphere.

sec.title: Specimen preparation
sec.p: Films of 0.1–0.3 mm thickness were obtained by compression molding between plaques covered with Kapton® films, using a Carver Model B lab press, at 3000 lbf/in2 and 180°C for 3 min. The composite sheets were subsequently cooled in a cold press under similar conditions of time and pressure. The thicknesses were measured using a Käfer micrometer (Germany, 0.001 mm) or a Peacock micrometer (USA, 0.01 mm) and expressed as an average value of 10 measurements for the permeability specimens and as a median for the mechanical property specimens. These samples presented degree of crystallinity from 3.1 to 5.8% as measured by DSC.

sec.title: Nanocomposite characterization
sec.p: X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses were performed in a Rigaku Miniflex 6000 diffractometer using nickel-filtered CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) operating at 30 kV and 15 mA. The data were recorded over a 2θ range from 2 to 80° at 2θ rates of 0.05/min. The curves were treated with the Origin 6.0 software. The mica basal distances in the composites were calculated by the Bragg equation.

Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out on Zeiss 900 equipment (Germany) using an accelerator voltage of 80 kV. Ultrathin sections of the composites with a thickness of approximately 60–90 nm were prepared in a Reichert UltraCut S50 ultramicrotome equipped with a diamond knife. Samples were analyzed without any staining.

sec.title: Water vapor permeability
sec.p: The water vapor permeability was measured according to the ASTM E-96-90 method23 at 25°C. Films previously conditioned at 75% relative humidity/25°C for 48 h were introduced in distilled water and subsequently placed into a dessicator containing silica gel so that the pressure difference is the water pressure at 25°C (3.167 kPa). The weight gain/loss was tracked each day for 8 days to obtain a linear mass–time relationship. The water vapor permeability (Pva) is calculated using equation (1) as follows: (1)Pva=[(g/t)/A]/[(X/ΔP)], in which g = gain or loss of weight, t = time (h), A = permeation area (m2), X = thickness (mm) and ΔP = pressure difference (kPa). Pva was expressed in kg·m/m2·s·Pa · 10−7 g/h m.

sec.title: Tensile tests
sec.p: The mechanical tests were performed on an Instron model 5569 Dual Column Tabletop Testing System using the ASTM D9882A-97D23 method for specimens with dimensions of 10 × 1.0 cm and a thickness in the range of 0.20 to 0.60 mm. The specimens were previously conditioned for 48 h in an atmosphere of 50% relative humidity at 23°C. The test was carried out at a rate of 1.0 mm/min with a load cell of 10 kN. The results were expressed as an average of 7 measurements.

sec.title: Nanocomposite characterization
sec.p:
The morphology of the PLLA/Somasif MAE mica nanocomposites was investigated by XRD. The XRD curves are shown in Figure 1. The curve of the Somasif MAE mica (Figure 1(a)) presents four different peaks in the 2θ range from 1 to 10°, at 2θ = 2.9, 4.4, 4.8 e 7.2°, indicating a largest interlayer distance of 30.1 Å (2θ = 2.9°). Under the processing conditions, only a small change in the peak at 2θ = 2.9° was observed for the composites. This peak was shifted to a lower angle, indicating that the interlayer distance increased from 30.1 to 34.7–38.4 Å, which suggests some degree of polymer intercalation between the clay layers. Figure 1.
X-ray diffraction curves for (a) Somasif MAE and neat poly(lactic acid) (PLLA),1 PLLA/Somasif-MAE nanocomposites containing (b) 3 wt%, (c) 7 wt%, (d) 5% wt% of mica.

The peaks at 2θ = 4.4 and 7.2° were shifted to higher and lower angles, respectively, indicating a reduction and increase of the interlayer distance. Under some conditions, the intensity of the peak increased when the clay was added to the polymer, particularly at the concentration of 3 wt% under experimental condition of assay 4. A similar observation was reported by other authors.5,6,13,16

Table 2 presents the influence of the variables under investigation on the basal distance and shows that the rotor speed and clay concentration produced the greatest effects over this distance. The increase of the rotor speed increased the shear rate required to break the clay particles into individual platelets or small tactoids, i.e., aggregates of platelets with small thickness, increasing the degree of dispersion. On the other hand, the increase of the mica concentration favoured the increase of intercalation. The XRD curve of the nanocomposite containing 7 wt% of mica exhibited a similar pattern of the nanocomposite containing 3 wt% of the clay, which suggests that the processing factors exert the greatest effect at low clay concentrations. Figure 2 presents the TEM micrographs of PLLA/Somasif MAE nanocomposites and show the degree of clay dispersion of representative composites obtained under conditions of assay 2, assay 8 and assay10 at low (left) and high magnification (right). Figure 2(a) (assay 2) shows that the synthetic organophilic mica is well dispersed in the polymer matrix with no large-scale agglomeration. It is evident, however, that the mica particles is not exfoliated, remaining dispersed as small tactoids, i.e., aggregates of platelets with thickness of about 40–50 nm. Figure 2.
Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) micrographs of poly(lactic acid) (PLLA)/Somasif MAE nanocomposites prepared under conditions of assay 2 (190°C, 60 r/min, 3 wt% mica, 5 min) (a, d), assay 8 (170°C,120 r/min, 7 wt% mica, 15 min) (b, e) and assay 10 (180°C, 90 r/min, 5 wt% mica,10 min) (c, f).

It seems also that condition of assay 2 gives rise to a better dispersion than that obtained with conditions of assay 8 and assay 10 (Figure 2(b) (c)), in which large tactoids with thickness of about 200–300 nm are present. From the high magnification images (Figure 2(d)–(f)), it is evident that significant degree of exfoliation was not obtained because mica domains presents thickness higher than that expected for a synthetic mica monolayer. These TEM micrographs demonstrated also that dispersion levels are comparable to other polymer/clay nanocomposites reported in the literature.4,6

sec.title: Water vapor permeability
sec.p:
Figure 3 shows that the addition of synthetic mica to neat PLLA reduces the water vapor permeability with a maximum decrease of nearly 54% for the composite with the highest mica content (7 wt%). Such a decrease in the water vapor permeability is due to the known effect of increasing the internal tortuous paths by the dispersed layered-nanofiller. Similar results were reported in literature for nanocomposites obtained by casting.4,24,25 An examination of Figure 2(b) shows that the water vapor permeability is decreased despite the relatively large size of clay particles dispersed in the polymer matrix. It means that although the mica seems to be better dispersed into the polymer matrix in the sample of assay 2, the higher content of the filler in the sample of assay 8 has a more significant effect in the reduction of this property. Figure 3.
Water vapor permeability of neat poly(lactic acid) (PLLA) (PLA P) and PLLA/Somasif mica nanocomposites (Sample number corresponds to Assay number of Table 1).

In relation to the values found for the PLLA in the literature, it is observed that the results of this work (7.68 × 10−11 g m/m2 s Pa) are higher than those reported by Rhim et al.24 and Auras et al.26 (1.8 × 10−11 g m/m2 s Pa and 1.9–1.75 × 10−11 g m/m2 s Pa, respectively).

Comparing the values found in this work for PLLA/mica nanocomposite (3.8–5.0 × 10−11 g m/m2 s Pa) and a literature value for PLA/Cloisite 20A nanocomposite obtained by casting (1.5 × 10–11 g m/m2 s Pa),24 the PLLA/synthetic mica nanocomposite present higher permeability.

This difference is due to the complexity of the permeation phenomenon since the permeability is a function of diffusivity and solubility. These properties depend on the test conditions (temperature, pressure and relative humidity), the sample preparation conditions (casting, melt quenching, annealing), the polymer purity and the proportion of L/D enantiomers in the PLLA chain.27

sec.title: Tensile tests
sec.p:
Considering the estimated effects (Table 3), only the mixing time and clay concentration were significant to the tensile properties, because a reduction in the tensile strength and the elongation at break were observed with an increase in these parameters. The decrease in these tensile properties (Figures 4 and 5) for most of these polymer materials seems to have been influenced by the degree of clay dispersion in the polymer matrix as well as by the decrease in molecular weight. It is known that molecular weight of PLLA can be decreased by thermal degradation when it is melt processed by prolonged processing times. This statement is supported by a previous work,28 in which a PLLA with Mw = 197,000 was processed in a mixer chamber with roller type rotor at 180°C, 80 r/min for 5 min and had the molecular weight decreased to 160,800. In the same work, the authors observed a decrease of Mw to 132,000 when 10 wt% of the mica Somasif MPE was added to the polymer.28 Figure 4.

So, the influence of filler dispersion on the mentioned tensile properties is in turn dependent on the polymer nature, the clay type and the processing conditions. An increase in these properties has been reported for conditions in which the clay platelets are exfoliated, which compensates for the effects of chain degradation that usually occur during melt blending, particularly in ordinary processing condition with a non-inert atmosphere.
A low degree of exfoliation is inadequate to maximize the tensile properties, and an increase in the clay concentration leads to tactoids formation and a reduction in the properties.12,29–31

In comparison with PLLA, a decrease in all tensile parameters is observed for the nanocomposites, probably due to a certain degree of reduction of the matrix molecular weight and probably due to the fact that the amount of the inorganic filler (maximum 4 wt% of synthetic mica) was inadequate to compensate this effect, resulting in no improvement in the tensile properties. The decrease in tensile strength and elongation at break has been reported in other works12,20,32 and is in agreement with the results of this work. Although other researchers have noted an increase in the maximum stress, elastic modulus and elongation at break, as expected, up to a maximum clay concentration, these properties also depend on the polymer/clay nature.8,31,33

As conclusion, in this study, the results of tensile properties can be attributed as the result of the state of the synthetic mica dispersion in the matrix in which only certain degree of intercalation was attained considering the RDX and TEM data (Figures 1 and 2).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this work, PLLA and the synthetic mica Somasif MAE composites were prepared by melt blending using a Haake mixer under different processing conditions, according to an incomplete factorial (24−1) experimental design. The synthetic mica particles were well dispersed in all conditions giving rise to PLLA/synthetic mica nanocomposites containing particles with size ranging from 40 to 300 nm. The introduction of the synthetic mica into neat PLLA decreased about 50% its permeability to water vapor. The variables that most affected the tensile properties were the mixing time and clay concentration, but the levels studied or the degree of intercalation/exfoliation were insufficient to significantly improve the tensile properties of these PLLA/Somasif mica nanocomposites.
